claim: London gets more international arrivals than Paris.

supporting.text: London is one of the world's most visited cities, with over 20 million international arrivals annually, according to the World Tourism Organization.

attacks.text: London is one of the world's most visited cities, with over 20 million international arrivals annually, according to the World Tourism Organization.
Paris also receives over 20 million international arrivals annually, according to the same World Tourism Organization data, making the claim ambiguous.
London's international arrivals include a significant number of business travelers, whereas Paris attracts more leisure tourists, which may skew the comparison.
The data from the World Tourism Organization may not account for regional or short-term visitors, which could favor Paris due to its central location in Europe.
London's airports handle more international flights than Paris, supporting the claim of higher international arrivals.

supporting.text: Paris is also a top tourist destination, but London's status as a global financial and business hub attracts more international travelers for both leisure and business.

attacks.text: Paris is also a top tourist destination, but London's status as a global financial and business hub attracts more international travelers for both leisure and business.
Paris has historically been the most visited city in the world, with higher tourism numbers than London in many years, according to international tourism reports.

While Paris has higher tourism numbers, London's broader definition of 'international arrivals' includes business travelers, which inflates its total compared to leisure-focused destinations like Paris.
The cultural and historical appeal of Paris, including landmarks like the Eiffel Tower and Louvre, draws a consistently higher volume of leisure travelers than London.
London's diversified economy and global connectivity through Heathrow Airport contribute to a higher volume of short-term business travelers, which are counted in international arrival statistics.

supporting.text: London has more international flight connections than Paris, with Heathrow Airport being one of the busiest in the world, contributing to higher international arrivals.

attacks.text: London has more international flight connections than Paris, with Heathrow Airport being one of the busiest in the world, contributing to higher international arrivals.
Paris has multiple major airports (Charles de Gaulle, Orly, Beauvais), collectively handling more international arrivals than London's airports when combined.
Heathrow's passenger traffic is heavily skewed toward transit passengers who do not count as arrivals in London, whereas Paris's airports serve more direct international visitors.
International arrivals include non-air travel (e.g., Eurostar trains), where Paris benefits from high-speed rail connections across Europe, surpassing London's rail arrivals.
Eurostar data shows London as the primary destination for international rail travelers, with more arrivals than Paris due to higher tourism and business demand.

supporting.text: The UK's historical and cultural ties to many countries, including former colonies, drive higher international tourism to London compared to Paris.

attacks.text: The UK's historical and cultural ties to many countries, including former colonies, drive higher international tourism to London compared to Paris.
France also has strong historical and cultural ties to former colonies, which similarly drive tourism to Paris.
The UK's colonial history is more recent and widespread than France's, leading to stronger contemporary tourism ties.
Other factors like visa policies, flight connectivity, and marketing efforts have a larger impact on international arrivals than historical ties.
Historical and cultural ties create long-term brand loyalty and repeat visitors, which are significant for tourism numbers.

supporting.text: Paris remains a leading tourist destination, but London's diverse economy and events (e.g., business conferences, concerts) attract a broader range of international visitors.

attacks.text: Paris remains a leading tourist destination, but London's diverse economy and events (e.g., business conferences, concerts) attract a broader range of international visitors.
Paris has historically higher tourist numbers due to iconic landmarks like the Eiffel Tower and Louvre, which draw more leisure travelers than London's business-focused attractions.
London's Heathrow Airport handles more international passengers annually than Paris's Charles de Gaulle, supporting the claim of higher international arrivals.
Many visitors to London are transit passengers, not staying long-term, whereas Paris attracts more dedicated tourists who contribute to longer stays.
London's cultural and entertainment events (e.g., West End shows, Wimbledon) attract high-spending international visitors who stay for extended periods.

supporting.text: Data from Eurostat and national tourism boards consistently show London receiving more international arrivals than Paris in recent years.

attacks.text: Data from Eurostat and national tourism boards consistently show London receiving more international arrivals than Paris in recent years.
The data may not account for day-trippers or short-term visitors who do not stay overnight, which could significantly undercount Paris's total arrivals.
Eurostat's methodology includes all border crossings, including those by land, which could inflate London's numbers due to its geographic connectivity.
The definition of 'international arrivals' varies between sources, and some may exclude EU travelers, disproportionately affecting Paris.
National tourism boards standardize their reporting to align with UNWTO definitions, minimizing discrepancies in 'international arrivals' metrics.
